# The Southern Company (SO) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

The Southern Company, through its subsidiaries, engages in the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity. The company develops, constructs, acquires, owns, and manages power generation assets, including renewable energy projects and sells electricity in the wholesale market; distributes natural gas in Illinois, Georgia, Virginia, and Tennessee; operates, constructs, and maintains approximately 78,500 miles of natural gas pipelines and 14 storage facilities; and provides gas marketing services, as well as electric services to retail customers. It also offers distributed energy and resilience solutions, and digital wireless communications and fiber optics services, as well as deploys microgrids for commercial, industrial, governmental, utility customers. The Southern Company was incorporated in 1946 and is headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia. Southern is one of the largest utilities in the US. The company serves 9 million customers with vertically integrated electric utilities in three states and natural gas distribution utilities in four states. It owns 44 gigawatts of rate-regulated generating capacity, primarily for serving customers in Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi.

## 2. Current Market Data

As of today, Southern(SO) shares are valued at $87.52. The company's market cap stands at 96.37B, with a P/E ratio of 21.59 and a dividend yield of 3.4%. In the last year, Southern(SO) shares hit a 52-week high of $100.84 and a 52-week low of $80.46. Southern Company (The) is going to release the next earnings report on Feb 12, 2026.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

The Southern Company (Southern Company) is a holding company. The Company owns all of the stock of the traditional electric operating companies and the parent entities of Southern Power Company (Southern Power) and Southern Company Gas, and owns other direct and indirect subsidiaries. The Company owns all of the common stock of Alabama Power Company (Alabama Power), Georgia Power Company (Georgia Power), and Mississippi Power Company (Mississippi Power), each of which is an operating public utility company. The primary business of the Southern Company system is electricity sales by the traditional electric operating companies and Southern Power and the distribution of natural gas by Southern Company Gas. The Company's segments include Gas distribution operations, Gas marketing services, Wholesale gas services, Gas Pipeline investments and All other.

Subsidiary Southern Power owns 13 gigawatts of natural gas generation and renewable energy across the US and sells the electricity primarily under long-term contracts. Southern Power's solar generating portfolio will total more than 2,920 MW. Southern Power's solar facilities are a part of the company's 5,450 MW renewable fleet, which consists of 30 solar and 15 wind facilities operating, planned or under construction.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

Southern Nuclear marked a pivotal moment for nuclear reliability in April 2025 by installing advanced Lead Test Assemblies at Plant Vogtle Unit 2—the first U.S. commercial reactor to use uranium enrichments above historical limits. Engineers loaded the old reactor with a new type of uranium fuel enriched above the traditional threshold and designed to withstand all kinds of accidents, last longer without refueling, and generate less radioactive waste. It's the first time in U.S. history a commercial reactor is running on fuel enriched above 5%. That may not sound like much, but many industry analysts recognize the redesigned uranium fuel as a monumental step change for the nuclear sector. "This is enabling us to get more out of those existing reactors than in the past," Jonathan Chavers, Southern's director of nuclear fuel and analysis, told Fortune exclusively.

Southern Company is investing in battery energy storage systems (BESS) to help ensure reliability during peak demand. Alabama Power is building the state's first ever utility-scale BESS facility with 150 MW capacity, equivalent to the capacity needed to power about 9,000 homes. In Georgia, following the construction of its first BESS facility in 2024, Georgia Power has projected 765 MW of new battery storage capacity by 2026.

Georgia Power and Mitsubishi Power achieved a global milestone at Plant McDonough-Atkinson by successfully blending hydrogen and natural gas at up to 50% on an advanced-class gas turbine—the largest test of its kind in the world. This breakthrough reduces carbon emissions by approximately 22% compared to 100% natural gas and demonstrates the potential of hydrogen to power a cleaner energy future.

To prepare for the future, Southern Company is planning to invest more than $80 billion over the next five years to strengthen the grid and deploy advanced technologies that make our system more resilient.

## 5. Growth Strategy

Southern Company is experiencing one of the most significant periods of growth in its history. Electric sales are projected to grow by 8% annually through 2029, driven by unprecedented projected energy demand from data centers, advanced manufacturing, and residential expansion across our footprint. This historic opportunity requires bold action, and we are ready.

Even as we rise to meet this challenge, affordability remains our top priority. Georgia Power will freeze base electric rates (excluding storm costs) through 2028, and Alabama Power will keep rates steady through 2027, giving families and businesses predictability at a time when many other costs are rising.

Based on our research and planning, shareholder and stakeholder dialogues, we believe our path to net zero by 2050 will be achieved through: Using natural gas to enable transition to lower emitting generating fleet · Expanding zero-carbon resources, including renewables and nuclear. We are also growing our investment in renewable energy, modernizing the grid to take full advantage of new technology, using natural gas to support our transition to a lower emitting generating fleet, building new nuclear generating units, continuing our robust research and development (R&D) efforts and investing in energy efficiency.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

Mississippi Power played a pivotal role in bringing Compass Datacenters' $10 billion hyperscale campus to Lauderdale County, one of the largest technology investments in the Southeast. The project will include eight data centers built over eight years, creating thousands of jobs and supporting Meridian with economic growth. By delivering approximately 500 megawatts of reliable energy and investing in critical infrastructure like a new substation at the I-20/59 Industrial Park, Mississippi Power helped ensure the site was ready for development.

Compass Datacenters builds single-tenant, hyperscale data center campuses. The large-scale campuses built by Compass are designed to last for more than 100 years and create economies of scale to support local businesses and jobs.

PowerSecure partnered with Edged Energy to deliver advanced electrical and mechanical systems for Atlanta's newest data center campus, designed with sustainability at its core.

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

Southern Company, parent company of Alabama Power, reported a growth in third-quarter 2025 earnings, raking in $1.7 billion or $1.55 per share, up from $1.5 billion this time last year. Third-quarter 2025 operating revenues were $7.8 billion, compared with $7.3 billion for the third quarter of 2024, an increase of 7.5%.

Power supplier The Southern Company SO reported third-quarter 2025 earnings per share (excluding certain one-time items) of $1.60, outperforming the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.50 and improving from the year-ago adjusted profit of $1.43. The encouraging numbers reflect investment in state-regulated utilities, along with usage and customer growth.

In 2024, The Southern Company's revenue was $26.72 billion, an increase of 5.83% compared to the previous year's $25.25 billion. Earnings were $4.40 billion, an increase of 10.69%.

For the nine months ended September 30, 2025, operating revenues were $22.6 billion, compared with $20.4 billion for the corresponding period in 2024, an increase of 10.7%.

The firm guided earnings per share of $4.30 — at the top end of its projected range — and 54 cents for the December quarter. Further, Southern Company management stuck to its long-term EPS growth rate projection of 5-7%.

## 11. Recent Developments

TheFly reported on December 16, 2025, that as part of its 2026 outlook for the utilities group, Morgan Stanley downgraded The Southern Company (NYSE:SO) from Equal Weight to Underweight and reduced its price objective to $81 from $97. According to the firm's research report, utility share performance is forecast to be driven by data centers and growth upside in 2026, with no slowdown in activity or alleviation of grid tightness. The rating adjustment and lowered valuation forecast were caused in part by Morgan Stanley's advice to investors to steer clear of political and regulatory risk, especially during an election year.

The firm expressed concern that a Democrat-majority commission could lead to "more efforts to manage customer bills" and potentially "less predictable regulatory outcomes" for Southern Co. While acknowledging Southern Co has taken proactive steps by establishing new data center contracts that offer customer bill offsets in coming years, Morgan Stanley indicated these measures would likely be insufficient to overcome investor concerns surrounding the election.

Southern Company's electric operating companies were named Top Utilities in Economic Development by Site Selection magazine. Georgia Power marked its 27th consecutive year on the list, helping create nearly 17,000 jobs and $9.1 billion in investments. Alabama Power supported projects totaling $3.1 billion and 2,900 jobs, while Mississippi Power attracted major investments, including Compass Datacenters' $10 billion project in Meridian.

## 12. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

**Buy Rating: 7.8/10**

**Estimated Fair Value: $96.50**

### Rating Justification:

**Strengths Supporting Rating:**
- Strong exposure to the AI/data center boom with electric sales projected to grow by 8% annually through 2029, driven by unprecedented projected energy demand from data centers, advanced manufacturing, and residential expansion
- Securing major data center clients like Compass Datacenters' $10 billion hyperscale campus in Mississippi providing 500 megawatts of power
- Nuclear innovation leadership with first U.S. commercial reactor running on fuel enriched above 5%, enabling "more out of those existing reactors than in the past"
- Solid financial performance with Q3 2025 EPS of $1.60, outperforming estimates of $1.50
- 2024 revenue of $26.72 billion, up 5.83%, with earnings of $4.40 billion, up 10.69%
- Strategic rate stability with Georgia Power freezing base rates through 2028 and Alabama Power through 2027

**Risk Factors:**
- Morgan Stanley downgrade due to "political and regulatory risk, especially during an election year"
- Analyst consensus of "Hold" rating with 12-month price target of $95.03
- Regulatory uncertainty around rate recovery for massive data center infrastructure investments

**Investment Thesis:**
Southern Company is uniquely positioned for the AI infrastructure boom with established data center partnerships and innovative nuclear capabilities. The 8% annual demand growth forecast through 2029 provides substantial visibility. While regulatory risks exist, the company's proactive customer rate management and diversified energy portfolio provide downside protection. The stock trades at reasonable valuations with a 3.4% dividend yield supporting income-focused growth investors.

The fair value of $96.50 represents approximately 10% upside potential based on improving fundamentals and data center demand tailwinds, balanced against regulatory headwinds.
